source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Autoclave testing in lithiated water solutions indicated a marked sensitivity of the niobium binaries to accelerated corrosion; only the ZIRLO alloy was superior to Zircaloy4 in this test regime.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Autoclave testing in lithiated water solutions indicated a marked sensitivity of the niobium binaries to accelerated corrosion; only the ZIRLO alloy was superior to Zircaloy4 in this test regime.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The in-reactor waterside corrosion performance of the ZIRLO alloy was better than that of reference Zircaloy-4 cladding.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The relative corrosion performance benefit of ZIRLO over Zircaloy-4 increased with increasing power levels.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The corrosion performance of the binary zirconium-niobium alloys showed locally thicker oxides and greater variability than exhibited by either ZIRLO or Zircaloy-4.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The ZIRLO alloy showed significantly lower in-reactor creep and rod growth than Zircaloy-4 and the niobium binary alloys.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The ZIRLO alloy showed significantly lower in-reactor creep and rod growth than Zircaloy-4 and the niobium binary alloys.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Both the autoclave tests and the BR-3 data show that ZIRLO will out-perform Zircaloy4 at very high exposures.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Both the autoclave tests and the BR-3 data show that ZIRLO will out-perform Zircaloy4 at very high exposures.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The linear growth of relatively thick (>300 nm, interference-colored oxide films on zirconium alloy specimens exposed in the Advanced Test Reactor (ATR) coolant at â¤55Â°C was unexpected.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: It was found that, in the laboratory, provided a high electric field was maintained across the oxide during ultraviolet (UV) irradiation, enhanced growth of oxide occurred in the irradiated area.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Similarly enhanced growth could be obtained on thin thermally formed oxide films that were immersed in an electrolyte with a high electric field superimposed.
